item.title: Shamima Begum can return to UK to fight for citizenship, Court of Appeal rules
item.description: The 20-year-old, who joined the Islamic State group in Syria in 2015, had her citizenship revoked in 2019.

item.title: Coronavirus: UK payrolls shrink by 649,000 jobs in lockdown
item.description: Official figures reveal a drop in the number in employment, with young people hard hit.

item.title: Major US Twitter accounts hacked in Bitcoin scam
item.description: Twitter says a hacking attack on employees was to blame for one of its biggest ever security lapses.

item.title: Jofra Archer excluded from second England-West Indies Test
item.description: England fast bowler Jofra Archer is excluded from the second Test against West Indies after breaching the bio-secure protocols.

item.title: Jen Reid: Bristol Black Lives Matter statue removed
item.description: An artist designed the sculpture of Jen Reid to replace the toppled Edward Colston statue in Bristol.

item.title: PM suggests York as Parliament's temporary home
item.description: MPs and peers may need to move while the Palace of Westminster undergoes restoration works.

item.title: Russia 'interference' report to be published
item.description: The intelligence watchdog will give its findings on alleged involvement in an election and the Brexit vote.

item.title: Boohoo: MPs demand answers over Boohoo exploitation claims
item.description: MP Philip Dunne says it is "shameful" it took the pandemic for the retailer to acknowledge issues.

item.title: Brad Parscale replaced as Trump's campaign manager
item.description: Brad Parscale was reportedly blamed by Donald Trump's inner circle for a botched rally in Oklahoma.

item.title: Coronavirus: Call to infect volunteers in Covid-19 vaccine hunt
item.description: Prominent scientists call for so-called "challenge trials" to accelerate vaccine development.

item.title: Climate change: Siberian heatwave 'clear evidence' of warming
item.description: The heatwave would have been almost impossible without human-caused climate change, a study says.

item.title: Major drive-in tour cancelled over virus fears
item.description: The tour was set to feature the hit musical Six, and performances by The Streets and Dizzee Rascal.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'My once-in-lifetime holiday hasn't been refunded'
item.description: A couple tell of their holiday refund "panic" as consumer group Which? calls for action from regulators.

item.title: Say Her Name: 'Black women are killed by police too'
item.description: The campaign group Say Her Name believes deaths of black women at the hands of police are overlooked.

item.title: Edward Enninful: British Vogue editor 'racially profiled' at work
item.description: Edward Enninful says he was racially profiled after being told to "use the loading bay" at his offices.

item.title: Adoptee Kara Bos's search for her roots in South Korea
item.description: Kara Bos was adopted as a baby from South Korea by a US couple. But her birth father is standing in the way of her discovering her roots.

item.title: Coronavirus holiday quiz: Do you know the rules about travelling abroad?
item.description: Take this quiz to test your knowledge of the government's advice on foreign holidays this summer.

item.title: The Papers: Coronavirus vaccine hopes and 'mask madness'
item.description: Hopes of a Covid-19 vaccine lead many of the papers while the debate on face masks continues.

item.title: Coronavirus: Seven tips for job hunters
item.description: As coronavirus puts huge strain on the jobs market, four experts offer advice for finding work.

item.title: Iran judiciary may halt protesters' executions after social media storm
item.description: The hashtag #do_not_execute trended after a court upheld the death sentences of three protesters.

item.title: Viola Davis: I betrayed myself and my people in The Help
item.description: The Oscar-nominated 2011 film was created in the "cesspool of systemic racism", the actress says.

item.title: Coronavirus: Restaurant no-shows 'putting jobs at risk'
item.description: TV chef Paul Ainsworth says 27 people failed to turn up for their booking at his pub on one day.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'How we’re surviving a second virus lockdown'
item.description: From star-gazing to Nintendo workouts - people facing lockdown again share what's keeping them sane.

item.title: Who is Shamima Begum and how do you lose your UK citizenship?
item.description: Ms Begum travelled to Syria to join the so-called Islamic State group in 2015.

item.title: Fertility rate: Shrinking population in six easy lessons
item.description: Research suggests most countries' populations will have shrunk by the end of the century.

item.title: Wayfair: The false conspiracy about a furniture firm and child trafficking
item.description: It's gone global, and involves a US-based furniture company and unfounded allegations of human trafficking.

item.title: My Money: 'I'm a sucker for a promo sticker'
item.description: Charmel Flemming from South Africa takes us through her week during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus: How Covid-19 hit the comedy industry
item.description: With many sectors of the leisure economy hit by coronavirus, what has been the effect on comedy?

item.title: Coronavirus in South Africa: Inside Port Elizabeth's 'hospitals of horrors'
item.description: A BBC investigation exposes chronic failures in the health system in one of the poorest areas.

item.title: OnlyFans: 'I started selling sexy photos online after losing my job'
item.description: The number of people signing up to sell adult content online has spiked during coronavirus.

item.title: England captain Farrell signs 'long-term' deal at relegated Saracens
item.description: England captain Owen Farrell will remain at Saracens following their relegation from the Premiership after signing a "long-term" deal.

item.title: Johnson-Thompson & Gemili join new independent athletes' body
item.description: Katarina Johnson-Thompson and Adam Gemili join the board of a new independent body designed to fight for the rights of track and field athletes.

item.title: Olympics Rewind Beijing: Usain Bolt wins 200m gold
item.description: BBC Sport looks back to the 2008 Beijing Olympics when Usain Bolt completed a brilliant sprint double by smashing the 200m world record.

item.title: Olympic Secrets: When Tom Daley thought he was being pranked by David Beckham
item.description: Great Britain diving star Tom Daley looks back, with his former team-mate Leon Taylor, at the time he thought he was being pranked by David Beckham at London 2012.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The number of people claiming benefits has surged, but the unemployment rate has barely moved. Why?

item.title: Coronavirus: Where can I now go on holiday in the UK?
item.description: Where can I go and what can do on a holiday in the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK's travel rules and which countries can you visit?
item.description: New agreements mean people entering the UK from certain countries will not have to quarantine.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Social distancing and lockdown rules are changing in England - but what can you now do?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding?
item.description: People at risk of becoming severely ill if they get coronavirus should take extra precautions.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Teams around the world are looking into medicines for Covid-19 and scientists are starting to discover what works.

item.title: Who won't have to wear face coverings in shops?
item.description: Questions about the face covering rule changes in England and other coronavirus topics.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does lockdown work in Leicester and on a Herefordshire farm?
item.description: Local lockdowns are in force on a Herefordshire farm and in Leicester, but how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: What powers do the police have?
item.description: Coronavirus lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but who is responsible for enforcing them?

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: When will we have one?
item.description: About 200 groups of medical researchers around the world are working on a vaccine for Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus immunity: Can you catch it twice?
item.description: Immunity is the crucial question and understanding it will tell us how the pandemic will end.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is a recession?
item.description: The world faces the worst recession for 80 years. But what does that mean?

item.title: Letters of love: 'Our father wrote every day as he waited to be sent to Auschwitz'
item.description: Daniele Israel's daily letters to his family from jail in Trieste paint a moving portrait of a family shattered by the Holocaust.
